title: AWK, oh AWK
description:
Kali ini kita membahas bash!

Baiklah tadi kita kuliah sysprog. Tapi sebelumnya pak Adin pernah ngomong ini

Ini sebenarnya mah gak perlu kuliah, wong bisa baca-baca di internet.. (informasinya gak perlu baca yang ada di buku -red)

and yeah, perkataan itu ada benarnya.

Saya melakukan ini di bash. Yuk kita lihat.

Saya punya berkas ini

Mufid@FIDZMOBILE ~/tes
$ cat lorem.txt
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod
tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam,
quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo
consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse
cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non
proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.

Di kuliah sysprog tadi, saya dikenalkan beberapa perintah yang common sense, yang semua pengguna unix pasti paham:

  • pipe (a | b) memberikan hasil output dari perintah a ke perintah b.
  • wc untuk word count. Tetapi juga bisa character cound dan line count.
  • head dan tail untuk mengambil beberapa bagian pertama atau beberapa bagian terakhir. Kombinasinya bisa mengeluarkan hanya baris dengan offset dan limit.

See? Sekarang berkenalan dengan AWK. Auch! Makhluk macam apa ini! Kenapa bisa ada sintaks dalam sintaks! Menyulitkan saja.

Ternyata tidak seperti yang saya pikirkan. AWK ini memiliki sintaks umum. Seperti biasa, [] adalah opsional.

[BEGIN { perintah1; perintah2; ... }] #baris1
[{ perintah1; perintah2; ... }]       #baris2
[END { perintah1; perintah2; ...}]    #baris3

setiap baris adalah opsional. Tetapi Yang paling make sense adalah baris2.

Coba perhatikan contoh berikut:

Mufid@FIDZMOBILE ~/tes
$ awk '{print $1;}' lorem.txt
Lorem
tempor
quis
consequat.
cillum
proident,

Mufid@FIDZMOBILE ~/tes
$ awk '{print $2;}' lorem.txt
ipsum
incididunt
nostrud
Duis
dolore
sunt

Mufid@FIDZMOBILE ~/tes
$ awk '{print $3;}' lorem.txt
dolor
ut
exercitation
aute
eu
in

Sudah mulai kelihatan?

Jadi pada dasarnya di awk itu juga ada perintah seperti print dan sub (perintah lengkap dapat Anda baca di http://www.grymoire.com/Unix/Awk.html atau seperti biasa man awk). Pada dasarnya AWK akan melakukan ini:

1. Membaca dan menjalankan di dalam {} yang didahului dengan `begin`, jika ada
2. Membaca setiap baris dan menjalankan di antara {} yang tidak didahului dengan `begin`, jika ada
3. Setelah selesai, mengeksekusi perintah di antara {} yang didahului dengan end, jika ada

Kemudian, setiap barisnya bisa dimodifikasi. Selain itu, Anda bisa memasukkan variabel sendiri di sini. Ya, seperti scripting pada umumnya. Adapun $n akan menampilkan kolom ke-n yang mana kolom itu dipisahkan oleh spasi (by default), dan jika n = 0 akan dikembalikan keseluruhan baris tersebut.

Terlalu abstrak?

Silahkan coba sendiri dan rasakan sensasinya :D

2. Membaca setiap baris dan menjalankan di antara {} yang tidak didahului dengan `begin`, jika ada
3. Setelah selesai, mengeksekusi perintah di antara {} yang didahului dengan end, jika ada

Kemudian, setiap barisnya bisa dimodifikasi. Selain itu, Anda bisa memasukkan variabel sendiri di sini. Ya, seperti scripting pada umumnya. Adapun $n akan menampilkan kolom ke-n yang mana kolom itu dipisahkan oleh spasi (by default), dan jika n = 0 akan dikembalikan keseluruhan baris tersebut.

Terlalu abstrak?

Silahkan coba sendiri dan rasakan sensasinya :D

title: Memoria
description:
Wah ternyata sudah 4 tahun yang lalu saya jadi bagian sebuah keluarga yang luar biasa, Rohis 1 Depok. Tepat seminggu kemarin, acara Latihan Dasar Kepemimpinan (LDK) dilaksanakan, meskipun di LDK ini saya gak terlalu kontributif (Baca: gak bisa “ngomel2″), tapi LDK kemarin cukup mem-”flash back” memori jaman dulu (berasa tua).
Ya.. ternyata sudah 4 tahun.. Apa kabar Rohis 1 Depok?


Apa kabar Paket Ramadhan Spesial (Paras) yang mulai maju tanggalnya? Kalau ingat cerita dulu, tentang pemilihan calon ketua Paras.

“Aji, Azhar, Rama, Umar, Agus ayo ikut ane”. kata seorang kakak kala itu, menginterupsi rapat rohis yang sedang berlangsung. Saya dan teman-teman dipanggil dan dipisah dari gerombolan, dibawa ke tempat yang agak jauh. “Dari antum berlima, akan kami pilih untuk jadi ketua PARAS”. Sebuah rapat terpisah, untuk memusyawarahkan siapa yang akan menjadi pemimpin di acara akbar tahunan ROHIS yang datang tiap Ramadhan itu, dan saya salah satu calonnya. Yang jelas dengan segala ke-egoisan yang ada, pembelaan-pembelaan ketidakmampuan keluar dari mulut saya, mau OSN lah, mau fokus di Student Club lah. Hingga pada akhirnya, tak ada satupun dari 5 nama itu yang keluar. Di tengah kepusingan, entah kenapa seorang teman sebut saja Adib, melintas. Waktu itu ia belum masuk Rohis. Dengan setengah putus asa (dan mungkin stress), kami berkata, “Adib, lu aja yang jadi ketua Paras”. Di luar dugaan, Adib mengiyakan. Jadilah iya, ketua PARAS, padahal belum masuk Rohis.

Teringat juga tentang divisi Syi’ar. katanya tahun ini mau di ‘hidupkan lagi’ ya? sejak 4 tahun lalu pertama kali dicetuskan, perpaduan antara divisi buletin dan seni dan olahraga. “Kalau antum jadi kepala divisi, antum siap gak?”. Kata senior setengah membentak kala itu, LDK Rohis 4 tahun silam. “Enggak bang”. Jawab saya PeDe. Ah tapi pada akhirnya tetap saja saya yang jadi kepala divisinya. Tapi untunglah, darinya saya belajar apa itu arti pemimpin.

Atau tentang masa-masa menjelang OSN dimana kita sesama pengurus Rohis belajar bersama di Al-wustho. Waktu itu anak rohis identik sekali dengan siswa yang berprestasi.

atau saat kita rela kehujanan untuk menjaga terpal supaya kambing untuk qurban tidak kehujanan.

saat kita ber-olah raga bersama berkeliling UI untuk riyadhoh Rohis. Waktu itu saat games mengisi plastik dengan air hingga penuh, ada yang berteriak “airnya bolong!”. Yang bolong itu plastiknya, bukan airnya.

saat kebimbangan menunggu kiriman cerpen untuk bahan buletin yang tak kunjung di kirim, padahal besok harus pergi selama 1 bulan untuk pelatihan rutin Tim olimpiade.

saat pertama kalinya saya naik ke atap mushola Al-wustho untuk foto Rohis bersama.

saat ngobrol bersama di sudut musholla di kala senja.

ternyata sudah 4 tahun…

Sejak tongkat estafet perjuangan itu berpindah, kini segala cerita-cerita tentangnya selalu membuat rindu. maaf untuk waktu-waktu yang terbuang, amanah-amanah yang tak tuntas, atau untuk langkah-langkah yang tak terkordinasi.

title: Sim simi (Lagi kurang kerjaan)
description:
Sim simi! Ini adalah sejenis chat-bot, yaitu semacam aplikasi chatting yang pakai artificial Intelligence, jadi kita bisa chatting sama mesin/komputer gitu. Layak dicoba bagi yang mau ngobrol tapi nggak punya teman #eh. BTW ini bukan kali pertama saya nyoba-nyoba sama mesin chatting sih, dulu skitar 2 tahun lalu sempet nyoba namanya iGod. (postingan tentang iGod: http://alhamfikri.net/index.php/chat-with-god/)
Sim Simi ini, dia uniknya adalah dia ini bahasanya agak luwes dan (sok) bersahabat, jadi terkesan lebih manusiawi. meskipun kayaknya sering nggak nyambung.

Ok, ini dia hasil ngobrol-ngobrol sama sim simi (kuning= simsimi, abu-abu = saya)


(gombal maut)

(ngomongin si Azhar mantan ketua Rohis dulu pas SMA )

title: Hotot as Alternative Twitter Client for Ubuntu
description:
Iseng-iseng browsing dan menemukan bahwa ada Twitter client alternatif selain Gwibber atau Tweetdeck yaitu Hotot. Sampai tulisan ini dibuat gw lebih prefer pakai Hotot daripada Gwibber maupun Tweetdeck selain karena tampilannya oke, Hotot juga cepat.

Cara install-nya mudah sekali:

  1. Tambah PPA repository dengan perintah 
    $ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:hotot-team
  2. Update dan install Hotot 
    $ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install hotot

Feel free to report any bugs!

(sumber: sini)

title: Install Sublime Text 2 via PPA in Ubuntu
description:
Beberapa hari yang lalu dapet rekomendasi dari Ashar Fuadi mengenai text editor yang oke banget yaitu Sublime Text 2.

Berikut ini cara install Sublime Text 2 via PPA:

  1. Buka terminal (Ctrl + Alt + T)
  2. Tambahkan PPA repository dengan perintah berikut 
    $ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:webupd8team/sublime-text-2
  3. Update dan install Sublime Text 2 
    $ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install sublime-text
  4. Sublime Text 2 berhasil ter-install!

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut tentang Sublime Text 2 bisa dibaca di sini. Feel free to report any bugs!

title: Buletin
description:
Lagi ngubek2 foto di HP, ketemu gambar ini:

Ini adalah foto dari Sebuah buletin islam di Jepang berjudul “What Is Islam”, di temukan di meja restoran sama tumpukan-tumpukan brosur2 (kalo gak salah, udah agak lupa dapet dimana. Sudah hampir setahun yang lalu, hehe). Buletinnya 90% ditulis dengan bahasa Jepang, dan saya cuman ngerti judulnya doang, isinya ? i have no idea. Biar begitu, entah kenapa ada perasaan haru, kagum, bangga, atau apalah pas pertama kali liat ini. Seperti secercah cahaya di kegelapan (apa coba)

Hmm, Islam itu minoritas di Jepang, tapi berda’wah dan men-syi’arkan Islamnya tetap jalan. Gimana nih kita yang di Indonesia dengan kuantitas yang banyak, harus bisa lebih maksimal dong syi’ar-nya

—

title: Ramadhan!
description:
Syukur alhamdulillah gw masih dikasih kesempatan untuk bertemu Ramadhan tahun ini. Meski lagi-lagi terjadi perbedaan dalam hal penentuan awal puasa (19 atau 20 Juli 2012) tetap saja seluruh Muslim di dunia berbahagia menyambut kedatangan Ramadhan, termasuk gw tentunya.

Satu hal yang paling gw sukai di bulan Ramadhan–selain pahala yang berlipat-lipat ganda, tertutupnya semua pintu neraka dan dibukanya semua pintu surga, sampai dibelenggunya setan-setan pengganggu manusia–adalah bahwa semua orang berlomba-lomba beribadah. Artinya, Ramadhan merupakan momen tepat untuk memperbaiki diri. Jika sebelumnya jarang shalat sunah, jarang shalat berjamaah, dan lain-lain, maka kalau di Ramadhan ini hal-hal tersebut dilaksanakan, tidak akan ada omongan-omongan seperti, “Ih tumben banget lo,” atau “Sok alim banget, cih”, atau sejenisnya karena memang peningkatan ibadah sangat wajar terjadi di bulan suci ini.

Semoga kita semua diizinkan oleh-Nya meraih kemenangan di bulan Ramadhan ini! Aamiin.

title: (Akhirnya) Dilema Anak Olimpiade yang Terjawab
description:
Kabar baik nih, buat teman-teman SMA yang memilih menjalani hidup sebagai anak olimpiade . Selepas penutupan pelatnas 3 tim olimpiade komputer kemarin, pihak diknas mengumumkan bahwa sekarang, Fasilkom UI bisa menerima 16 besar tim olimpiade komputer untuk masuk tanpa tes (kalau tanpa biaya, saya masih belum tahu). Akhirnya ada kemajuan juga setelah 2 tahun lalu saya akhirnya bisa masuk Fasilkom dengan jalur yang mungkin sama, hanya saja waktu itu terbatas untuk 8 besar. Ya, waktu itu saya diterima tanpa tes dan bebas uang pangkal + bebas uang kuliah, moga-moga yang sekarang juga bebas biaya.

—

Sebuah kebijakan yang menjawab dilema sebagai anak olimpiade (dulu juga merasakan ).

“Loh, kan anak Olimpiade, anak-anak pinter dong, kenapa harus bingung kalau mau kuliah di PTN?”. ets, jangan salah, sampai sekarang Indonesia itu masih kurang memperhatikan yang seperti ini. Seleksi masuk PTN masih terlalu kaku, harus SNMPTN, Simak, atau ujian-ujian lainnya. Padahal kalau mereka mau tahu, anak-anak olimpiade, komputer misalnya, mereka sudah mempelajari pelajaran-pelajaran kuliah semester 6, bahkan pelajaran S2 saat masih SMA.

Apa alasannya (paling tidak buat saya pribadi) anak olimpiade susah masuk PTN? Salah satu ‘kewajiban’ anak olimpiade adalah mengikuti pelatihan + seleksi, dimana pelatihan itu dilakukan sampai 4x, dan tiap pelatihan waktunya bisa mencapai 3 minggu. Artinya kita harus dispen dari dunia persekolahan dan ikut pelatihan itu. Tidak hanya itu, kalau di tim olimpiade komputer itu sendiri, sebelum pelatihan kita juga ada pra-pelatihan yang dilakukan online, selama sekitar 2-3 minggu.

Artinya, tantangan pertama kita adalah membagi waktu untuk pelajaran sekolah dengan untuk belajar pelajaran olimpiade + ikut pelatihan. Kalau mau tembus sampai internasional, tentu jam terbang untuk latihan itu tidak cukup sekedar 1-2 jam sehari. Pengalaman saya dulu, saya menghabiskan waktu bisa sampai 5 – 6 jam sehari untuk belajar programming dan algoritma. Biasanya malam-malam dan siangnya sudah habis dipakai organisasi atau kegiatan lainnya. Karena gak sempat lagi buat belajar pelajaran sekolah, otomatis ranking saya anjlok. Lantas mau masuk PTN lewat mana? SNMPTN Undangan impossible karena nggak ranking dan ikut SIMAK pun agak-agak hopeless karena ga pernah belajar. Sedikit cerita juga dulu (tahun 2009) beberapa teman saya tidak jadi masuk UI, dengan alasam sepele. Waktu ujian SIMAK bentrok dengan waktu pelatihan.

Lalu kalau masuk PTN sulit, biasanya anak olimpiade kuliah dimana? Jawabannya mudah ditebak, ke luar negeri. Universitas yang sangat welcome terhadap anak-anak olimpiade ini biasanya NTU dan NUS. Mereka menawarkan beasiswa untuk para bocah-bocah olimpiade, termasuk juga saya ditawari waktu itu. Hanya saja ada hal-hal yang membuat saya tetap mau kuliah di Indonesia. Karena ke-ngototan saya yang tetep mau kuliah di Indonesia, terutama Depok, maka saya mulai cari cara gimana supaya bisa masuk Fasilkom. Yang jelas selain lewat tes tulis karena bercermin sama kemampuan akademis eksak yang anjlok. Maka waktu itu saya e-mail pembina tim olimpiade komputer yang kebetulan juga Dosen UI supaya diberikan solusi. Singkat cerita, akhirnya Fasilkom mau menerima saya tanpa tes dan tanpa biaya . Mungkin cara ini bisa dicoba untuk teman-teman olimpiade yang mau kuliah di PTN tapi bingung cara masuknya.

#ini kenapa jadi cerita masa lalu?

Yah intinya sekarang ini Fasilkom menerima 16 besar TOKI (Tim olimpiade Komputer Indonesia) tanpa tes, dan moga-moga PTN lain dan bidang olimpiade lain juga mulai diperlancar jalur masukknya. Mereka ini aset bangsa, kalau nggak di urus, ya bakal kabur ke singapur, jerman, atau yang lainnya

(Note: Sebenarnya dari pemerintah sudah ada beasiswa untuk anak Olimpiade namanya OSI, itu adalah beasiswa untuk biaya kuliah. Namun untuk beasiswa masuk kuliah tanpa tes, masih jarang PT yang memberikan beasiswa tersebut)

Selepas penutupan pelatnas 3 tim olimpiade komputer kemarin, pihak diknas mengumumkan bahwa sekarang, Fasilkom UI bisa menerima 16 besar tim olimpiade komputer untuk masuk tanpa tes (kalau tanpa biaya, saya masih belum tahu). Akhirnya ada kemajuan juga setelah 2 tahun lalu [...]

content:encoded.#:
Kabar baik nih, buat teman-teman SMA yang memilih menjalani hidup sebagai anak olimpiade . Selepas penutupan pelatnas 3 tim olimpiade komputer kemarin, pihak diknas mengumumkan bahwa sekarang, Fasilkom UI bisa menerima 16 besar tim olimpiade komputer untuk masuk tanpa tes (kalau tanpa biaya, saya masih belum tahu). Akhirnya ada kemajuan juga setelah 2 tahun lalu saya akhirnya bisa masuk Fasilkom dengan jalur yang mungkin sama, hanya saja waktu itu terbatas untuk 8 besar. Ya, waktu itu saya diterima tanpa tes dan bebas uang pangkal + bebas uang kuliah, moga-moga yang sekarang juga bebas biaya.

—

Sebuah kebijakan yang menjawab dilema sebagai anak olimpiade (dulu juga merasakan ).

“Loh, kan anak Olimpiade, anak-anak pinter dong, kenapa harus bingung kalau mau kuliah di PTN?”. ets, jangan salah, sampai sekarang Indonesia itu masih kurang memperhatikan yang seperti ini. title: Install MySQL in Ubuntu 12.04
description:
Cukup ketikkan perintah

$ sudo apt-get install mysql-server

Untuk memudahkan dalam membuat table, memasukkan data, dan lain-lain, install juga phpMyAdmin dengan langkah-langkah yang bisa dilihat di sini.

Perlu diingat bahwa webserver seperti Apache harus diinstal terlebih dahulu. Langkah-langkah untuk menginstalnya dapat dilihat di sini.

Feel free to report any bugs

title: Error NO PUBKEY
description:
Kadang-kadang saat kita melakukan update, muncul pesan error “NO PUBKEY blablabla” dengan sederetan nomor. Salah satu cara untuk mengatasinya adalah dengan menjalankan perintah

$ sudo apt-key adv --keyserver keyserver.ubuntu.com --recv-keys <key-number>

dengan <key-number> adalah sederetan nomor yang muncul pada pesan error tersebut.

title: On Integrity.
description:
Someone might argue that it’s good we failed to find these pieces of code. Most of the infections occurred in politically turbulent areas of the world, in countries like Iran, Syria and Sudan. It’s not known exactly what Flame was used for, but it’s possible that if we had detected and blocked it earlier, we might have indirectly helped oppressive regimes in these countries thwart the efforts of foreign intelligence agencies to monitor them. But that’s not the point. We want to detect malware, regardless of its source or purpose. Politics don’t even enter the discussion, nor should they. Any malware, even targeted, can get out of hand and cause “collateral damage” to machines that aren’t the intended victim. Stuxnet, for example, spread around the world via its USB worm functionality and infected more than 100,000 computers while seeking out its real target, computers operating the Natanz uranium enrichment facility in Iran. In short, it’s our job as an industry to protect computers against malware. That’s it.

Mikko Hypponen on the failure of antivirus industry to catch Flame and Stuxnet

title: Sebuah Definisi
description:
Kata mereka, bahagia itu adalah ketika kau berkumpul bersama dalam gurauan dan obrolan sembari di iringi alunan gitar. Tawa lepas itu bisa jadi cara paling ampuh untuk melupakan sejenak tekanan tekanan hidup, Mungkin.

Kalau kata dia, bahagia itu adalah sebuah rumah megah dengan perhiasan-perhiasan mengkilap di dalamnya. Tak lupa dengan kendaraan kendaraan pribadi yang harganya mahal.

Ada juga yang bilang, bahagia itu se-sederhana bisa melihat senyum-senyum tulus dari orang-orang di sekitar mereka.

Dari sebuah pertanyaan, bisa muncul beragam jawaban, tergantung kepada siapa kamu bertanya. Nyatanya tidak hanya itu, kesedihan, ketakutan, harapan, setiap orang berhak punya definisi masing-masing atas apapun. Tak ada yang absolut. Apapun sudut pandangmu tentang hal itu, itu terserah. Kamu punya hak penuh untuk memaknai mereka.

Pandangan kita akan kehidupan ini akan mencerminkan setiap tindakan dan sikap kita. Mengapa? sederhana, kalau kamu anggap sukses itu ada pada secarik kertas ujian dan klasemen peringkat akademis sekolahmu, bisa jadi kamu selalu terjaga setiap malam ditemani setumpuk buku-buku pelajaran, berlelah-lelah mengejar angka sembilan koma.

Definisimu akan kesuksesan dan kegagalan akan mempengaruhi semangat juangmu.

Definisimu tentang kecantikan dan ketampanan akan mempengaruhi penampilanmu.

Dari definisi-definisi sederhana kita akan sesuatu, disanalah tergambar arah hidup kita. Sekarang tinggal bagaimanakah kamu memaknai sesuatu di sekitarmu. Kalaupun kamu bukan seorang filsafat atau profesor, yang bisa merangkai definisi atas sesuatu, tak ada yang melarangmu untuk mengikuti definisi orang lain. Kalau kamu masih bingung arti dari pemimpin, coba tanyakan itu pada Umar Bin Khattab yang selalu memastikan tak ada rakyatnya yang lapar. Mungkin kamu dapatkan jawaban darinya. Kalau kamu masih bingung esensi dari prestasi, mungkin bisa kau bertanya pada Al-Fatih, sang penakluk muda yang tak pernah bolong shalat malamnya. Mungkin kamu dapatkan inspirasi darinya.

Dari sebuah definisi, sesungguhnya kita mulai mencipta langkah. Mau kau kemanakan langkahmu? Jannah-Nya atau Jahannam-Nya?

title: How to Install and Configure Apache and PHP in Ubuntu
description:
Langkah-langkahnya sebagai berikut:

  1. Buka terminal (Ctrl + Alt + T)
  2. Install Apache 2 dan PHP 5 (versi tsb adalah yang terbaru pada saat tulisan ini dibuat) dengan mengetikkan perintah 
    $ sudo apt-get install apache2 php5 libapache2-mod-php5
  3. Setelah proses instalasi selesai, lakukan konfigurasi terlebih dahulu dengan menyunting berkas /etc/apache2/httpd.conf. Ketikkan perintah 
    $ sudo gedit /etc/apache2/httpd.conf

    Berkas tersebut pada awalnya kosong. Sekarang cukup tambahkan baris

    ServerName localhost

    pada berkas tersebut. Simpan dan keluar.

  4. Jalankan Apache dengan mengetikkan perintah 
    $ sudo /etc/init.d/apache2 restart
  5. Semua web files berada di direktori /var/www/ dan Anda sudah bisa mulai membuat web di localhost Anda.

Feel free to report any bugs!

(sumber: sini dan sini)

author: Kemal Maulana

rss:title.#: How to Install and Configure Apache and PHP in Ubuntu

rss:description.#: Langkah-langkahnya sebagai berikut: Buka terminal (Ctrl + Alt + T) Install Apache 2 dan PHP 5 (versi tsb adalah yang terbaru pada saat tulisan ini dibuat) dengan mengetikkan perintah $ sudo apt-get install apache2 php5 libapache2-mod-php5 Setelah proses instalasi selesai, … Continue reading →

content:encoded.#:
Langkah-langkahnya sebagai berikut:

  1. Buka terminal (Ctrl + Alt + T)
  2. Install Apache 2 dan PHP 5 (versi tsb adalah yang terbaru pada saat tulisan ini dibuat) dengan mengetikkan perintah 
    $ sudo apt-get install apache2 php5 libapache2-mod-php5
  3. Setelah proses instalasi selesai, lakukan konfigurasi terlebih dahulu dengan menyunting berkas /etc/apache2/httpd.conf. Ketikkan perintah 
    $ sudo gedit /etc/apache2/httpd.conf

    Berkas tersebut pada awalnya kosong. Sekarang cukup tambahkan baris

    ServerName localhost

    pada berkas tersebut. Simpan dan keluar.

  4. Jalankan Apache dengan mengetikkan perintah 
    $ sudo /etc/init.d/apache2 restart
  5. Semua web files berada di direktori /var/www/ dan Anda sudah bisa mulai membuat web di localhost Anda.

Feel free to report any bugs!

title: Some Good Tips I Learned in SRM 543
description:
I finished SRM 543 with only 170++ points, solving only the 250-pointer. Actually, I did solve the 500-pointer, but I forgot to erase a huge unused array that made my program used ~ 70 MB and thus failed due to memory limit. That was my second time failing a Medium for a stupid MLE bug. The first time was when I forgot to decrease the first dimension of a 2D DP array from N to 2 after I decided to “flying table” optimization.

As usual, after the match was over, I had some chats with other coders in the Arena. This time I discussed with vexorian and writer (which happened to be espr1t) about how to avoid such stupid bug. Here is a list of tips I learned from them.

  • If you use an external editor to code your solution, make sure you test your solution for the largest case in the Arena before submitting. This is to make sure that your solution don’t get TLE/MLE in the largest case.
  • To quickly enter the largest case in the Arena’s test feature, create a program that can generate and output that quickly. For example, a program that generates array of 50 random integers, array 50 “1,000,000,000″s, array of random strings, etc. in TopCoder’s input format, like “{100, 100, 100, …, 100}”.
  • Don’t read the example cases when you are solving a problem. Only read them if the statement is too confusing or you fail some of the examples when running your completed solution.
  • TopCoder’s C++ compiler uses -O2 compiler optimization. You should also turn on that option when testing your solution in external editor.

I think I’m going to follow those pieces of advice and see if they improve my performance.

content:encoded.#:
I finished SRM 543 with only 170++ points, solving only the 250-pointer. Actually, I did solve the 500-pointer, but I forgot to erase a huge unused array that made my program used ~ 70 MB and thus failed due to memory limit. That was my second time failing a Medium for a stupid MLE bug. The first time was when I forgot to decrease the first dimension of a 2D DP array from N to 2 after I decided to “flying table” optimization.

As usual, after the match was over, I had some chats with other coders in the Arena. This time I discussed with vexorian and writer (which happened to be espr1t) about how to avoid such stupid bug. Here is a list of tips I learned from them.

  • If you use an external editor to code your solution, make sure you test your solution for the largest case in the Arena before submitting. This is to make sure that your solution don’t get TLE/MLE in the largest case.
  • To quickly enter the largest case in the Arena’s test feature, create a program that can generate and output that quickly. For example, a program that generates array of 50 random integers, array 50 “1,000,000,000″s, array of random strings, etc. in TopCoder’s input format, like “{100, 100, 100, …, 100}”.
  • Don’t read the example cases when you are solving a problem. Only read them if the statement is too confusing or you fail some of the examples when running your completed solution.
  • TopCoder’s C++ compiler uses -O2 compiler optimization. You should also turn on that option when testing your solution in external editor.

I think I’m going to follow those pieces of advice and see if they improve my performance.

title: Drama Laptop Rusak
description:
Alkisah di suatu rumah yang sederhana di tengah kota yang masih berkembang, pada tanggal 11 Mei 2012 terjadilah sebuah bencana yang sungguh tragis: sebuah laptop* tiba-tiba tidak bisa menyala. 


Memangnya kenapa kalau dia ga bisa nyala? Oh, tentu saja sang pemilik laptop** hatinya galau tidak terkira, sebab tugas-tugasnya dikerjakan disitu semua, dokumen2 penting juga disana semua. Lah, masa ga bikin backup? Tentu saja sang pemilik laptop sudah dengan teratur dan rajinnya membuat backup data di sebuah harddisk yang usianya kurang lebih sama dengan si laptop itu. Sayangnya harddisknya rusak duluan sehari sebelumnya =_= sungguh malang.


Sang pemilik laptop yang gundah gulana hatinya pun segera mencari tahu apakah gerangan sebenarnya yang terjadi dengan laptop kesayangannya. Ia bertanya kepada mbah Gugel***, juga kepada rekan-rekan seperjuangannya di fakultas tempat ia belajar****. Dengan berat hati ia menerima kenyataan bahwa sepertinya laptop tercintanya tidak bisa ia selamatkan.


Tapi orang lain mungkin bisa, ya kan? Ya, sang pemilik laptop juga berpikir demikian. Maka ia mulai mencari tahu siapakah gerangan kiranya yang bisa membantunya. Kembali ia bertanya kepada mbah Gugel, hingga akhirnya ia mendapatkan informasi dimana lokasi-lokasi yang bisa ia datangi untuk menghidupkan kembali laptopnya itu*****. Ia pun segera menemukan seorang sahabat untuk menemaninya dalam perjalanan yang harus ditempuh, dan dengan sabar ia menunggu hari dimana ia bisa melakukan perjalanan menuju tempat yang dimaksud******.

Sembari menunggu hari itu datang, untuk sementara ia menggunakan laptop milik ibunya untuk mengerjakan tugas-tugas akademis dan non-akademisnya (yang Alhamdullillah bisa selesai tepat waktu meskipun ia harus mengulang tugas tersebut).

Ketika hari yang dimaksud tiba, ia menghubungi nomor telepon dari tempat-tempat yang akan ia datangi. Sayang seribu sayang, tiada yang menjawab panggilan tersebut. Sepertinya pemilik tempat itu sedang meliburkan diri ya. Benar, itu pula yang dipikirkan sang pemilik laptop. Ketidakpastian tersebut membuatnya mengurungkan niat untuk melakukan perjalanan untuk sementara ini.

Baginya, hidup terasa lebih sulit tanpa kehadiran laptopnya. Bahwa laptopnya akan menemaninya seperti sedia kala pun adalah sebuah hal yang tidak belum pasti terjadi. Namun tentunya ia menyadari bahwa Tuhan tidak akan memberi beban melebihi kesanggupan hamba-Nya, bahwa segala sesuatu pasti ada hikmahnya, dan bahwa dibalik segala kesulitan pasti ada kemudahan :)


(sepertinya) bersambung...

______
*laptop saya
**saya sendiri
***mesin pencari google.com
****teman-teman Fasilkom UI
*****pusat servis laptop untuk laptop dengan merek yang sama dengan merek laptop saya
******long weekend ini

title: Tentang Mimpi
description:
Mimpi tak harus tertidur. Di sudut ruangan kita menatap langit langit, atau di pinggir jalan kita duduk diam. Lalu kita mulai berfantasi, tentang rumah megah, tentang menjelajahi seisi dunia, tentang status-status terhormat, tentang seorang teduh pelengkap jiwa. Tetang apapun itu, yang berubah menjadi bahan bakar semangat yang menjadi energi penggerak setiap langkah langkah kita.

Mimpi itu energi yang terus membakar semangat kita. Kalau kita bicara angka “prestatif” tiga koma, atau sebuah piala yang terpajang di sudut rak. Kalau itu mimpi kita, energinya terlalu kecil dan akan cepat habis. Entah karena sadar bahwa mimpi itu tak lagi terjangkau. Kalaupun berhasil, lalu apa? berhentikah sampai di situ?

Mari kita bicara bicara tentang hal yang lebih besar lagi, sebuah beasiswa luar negeri. Untuk mendapatkan beasiswa, butuh prestasi akademis yang gemilang. Kita berimajinasi tentang itu, membayangkan kondisi visual dari khayalan kita. Ketika pada akhirnya kita berhasil mewujudkan hal itu, tanpa sadar angka tiga koma, atau piala-piala di sudut rak itu pun ikut bersama kita.

Maka bermimpilah setinggi – tingginya mimpi. Bukan lagi sekedar bangunan megah, atau status terhormat. Lebih dari itu, bayangkan senyum lepas mereka, yang kita bantu dengan sedekah sedekah kita. Atau tentang sebuah negara yang makmur dan damai, dibawah kepemimpinan kita. Marilah kita bermimpi menembus batas dunia, dan rasakan setiap nafas untuk menggapainya menjadi bermakna.

Dan barang siapa yang menghendaki kehidupan akhirat dan berusaha kearah itu dengan sungguh-sungguh sedang ia adalah seorang muslim, maka mereka itu adalah orang-orang yang usahanya dibalas dengan baik (Al Isra : 19)

title: Unofficial Behind the Scene: Life Up to the Fullest
description:
Life Up to the Fullest ini adalah film pendek hasil karya pengurus FUKI 2011.

Ini film proyek film pertama dimana gw terlibat, dan alhamdullillah menurut gw lumayan sukses xD

Btw, indikator sukses versi gw adalah filmnya selesai tepat waktu dan dapat respon yang positif dari banyak orang :) kalau ada respon positif, berarti 'pesan'nya cukup tersampaikan kan~

Disini mau share sedikit mengenai bagaimana film ini dibuat pada September 2011 lalu, secara garis besar dan sejauh yang gw ingat + pahami. Siapa tahu bisa menginspirasi. Hehe

>> Pra-pembuatan film
Setelah berhasil membentuk tim dan mengatur pembagian kerja, langsung brainstorming mengenai pesan apa yang mau disampaikan dan bagaimana menyampaikannya, +jalan ceritanya.
Karena ada banyak orang, maka ada banyak ide, misalnya bikin stop motion, edit dari film yang sudah ada trus di dubbing, pake manusia aja, macam-macam lah. Akhirnya dipilihlah ide: pakai wayang kertas.

Setelah konsep filmnya jelas, maka sudah bisa disiapkan segala macam properti film dan pendukung-pendukungnya, misalnya papan yang dilapisin kertas hitam buat background, handycam, nyari tempat syuting yang pas, dll. Tim Kreatif & Artistik (yang terdiri dari akhwat-akhwat dan ikhwan-ikhwan yang berjiwa kreatif dan artistik) mulai sibuk membuat gambar-gambar+perlengkapan lain yang dibutuhkan.

>> Pembuatan Film
Syutingnya 'hanya' memakan waktu 2 hari, masing-masing dari siang sampai jam 8-9an malam di Fasilkom UI. Meski lumayan melelahkan tapi tetap menyenangkan, dan benar-benar puas waktu syutingnya selesai~
Perekaman video melibatkan hampir semua anggota tim pembuatan film, karena memang butuh banyak tangan (tebak tangan gw yang mana :p), berjalan paralel dengan tim penata suara yang lagi milih+ngedit lagu yang sesuai film.
Di tim pembuat film ini, produsernya adalah aktivis .XML (organisasi pecinta film di Fasilkom UI, ga cuma suka nonton, tapi juga suka membuat film), maka skill dan pengalamannya udah ga usah dipertanyakan lagi, tiap take pun selalu disertai aba-aba dan diawali dengan kemunculan kertas yang menandai scene ke berapa dan take ke berapa.
Perekaman suara narator dilakukan secara terpisah, setelah semua scene selesai direkam.

>> Editing Film
Setelah semua video scene dan rekaman narasi tersedia, baru mulai ngedit filmnya. Editornya Adobe Premier 8.0 yang gw dapat satu paket waktu beli laptop ini. Salah satu kendala yang bagi gw cukup menghambat adalah: ketiga editor belum terbiasa make software ini, jadi dengan deadline yang cukup mepet, sebenarnya waktu itu gw agak sangat cemas.
Tapi berkat dukungan dari berbagai pihak, terutama dari kakak produser yang ternyata cukup galak tegas akhirnya tugas tim editor bisa selesai tepat waktu :") dan langsung disempurnakan dengan iringan lagu-lagu oleh tim penata suara.

Banyak hal positif yang gw dapatkan dari pembuatan film ini. Misalnya jadi lebih dekat dan lebih akrab dengan teman-teman+senior-senior di FUKI, bukan modus lho, plus jadi sedikit lebih terbiasa ngedit video (di proyek film yang setelah film ini alhamdullillah jadi lebih lancar ngeditnya, karena ga harus 'meraba-raba' lagi) meskipun ga belum jadi expert seperti sejumlah teman gw yang ngedit sambil merem pun bisa.

Versi dengan kualitas video yang lebih bagus (dan lebih besar ukurannya) bisa ditonton di:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FSgePfgbfaU

>> Pembuatan Film
Syutingnya 'hanya' memakan waktu 2 hari, masing-masing dari siang sampai jam 8-9an malam di Fasilkom UI. Meski lumayan melelahkan tapi tetap menyenangkan, dan benar-benar puas waktu syutingnya selesai~
Perekaman video melibatkan hampir semua anggota tim pembuatan film, karena memang butuh banyak tangan (tebak tangan gw yang mana :p), berjalan paralel dengan tim penata suara yang lagi milih+ngedit lagu yang sesuai film.
Di tim pembuat film ini, produsernya adalah aktivis .XML (organisasi pecinta film di Fasilkom UI, ga cuma suka nonton, tapi juga suka membuat film), maka skill dan pengalamannya udah ga usah dipertanyakan lagi, tiap take pun selalu disertai aba-aba dan diawali dengan kemunculan kertas yang menandai scene ke berapa dan take ke berapa.
Perekaman suara narator dilakukan secara terpisah, setelah semua scene selesai direkam.

>> Editing Film
Setelah semua video scene dan rekaman narasi tersedia, baru mulai ngedit filmnya. Editornya Adobe Premier 8.0 yang gw dapat satu paket waktu beli laptop ini. Salah satu kendala yang bagi gw cukup menghambat adalah: ketiga editor belum terbiasa make software ini, jadi dengan deadline yang cukup mepet, sebenarnya waktu itu gw agak sangat cemas.
Tapi berkat dukungan dari berbagai pihak, terutama dari kakak produser yang ternyata cukup galak tegas akhirnya tugas tim editor bisa selesai tepat waktu :") dan langsung disempurnakan dengan iringan lagu-lagu oleh tim penata suara.

Banyak hal positif yang gw dapatkan dari pembuatan film ini. Misalnya jadi lebih dekat dan lebih akrab dengan teman-teman+senior-senior di FUKI, bukan modus lho, plus jadi sedikit lebih terbiasa ngedit video (di proyek film yang setelah film ini alhamdullillah jadi lebih lancar ngeditnya, karena ga harus 'meraba-raba' lagi) meskipun ga belum jadi expert seperti sejumlah teman gw yang ngedit sambil merem pun bisa.

Versi dengan kualitas video yang lebih bagus (dan lebih besar ukurannya) bisa ditonton di:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FSgePfgbfaU

@.title: Unofficial Behind the Scene: Life Up to the Fullest

title: Epic Twenty Years Old is Epic
description:
Sudah seminggu lebih sejak hari peringatan bertambah tuanya gw untuk yang ke 20.

Suatu hari yang pada dini harinya seseorang yang sungguh sangat baik hati menelepon gw khusus untuk ngucapin selamat ulang tahun. *dilanjutin ngobrol padahal gw masih setengah tidur.

Suatu hari yang pada pagi harinya gw dibangunin mama yang ngucapin selamat ulang tahun+doa buat anaknya yg lucu ini :">

Suatu hari yang pada pagi harinya untuk pertama kalinya sejak bertahun-tahun gw dinyanyiin lagu 'Happy Birthday' di kelas *terakhir waktu SD

Suatu hari dimana somehow mood gw begitu bagusnya sampai temen gw bingung.

Suatu hari yang pada malam harinya gw dicerca habis-habis selama rapat divisi yang 1.5 jam itu, sampai mood gw yang tadinya bagus itu hancur.

Suatu hari yang pada malam harinya setelah mereka mencerca gw setengah mati, mereka ketawa-ketawa *ternyata gw dikerjain

Suatu hari yang pada malam harinya gw dikasih kado super-unyu dari orang-orang baik hati yang tadi ngerjain gw itu. 

Suatu hari yang pada malam harinya gw dateng telat ke 'acara' yang produsernya gw sendiri. *ditodong traktiran sama temans

Suatu hari dimana kegiatan luar rumah gw ditutup dengan quality time bersama orang-orang baik hati yang kalau ga ada mereka entah bagaimana jadinya hidup gw di kampus.

Suatu hari dimana gw diingatkan bahwa jatah usia gw berkurang setiap detiknya.

Suatu hari dimana gw sekali lagi diingatkan untuk teruuus bersyukur atas limpahan nikmat dari-Nya, 

atas kehidupan,

atas iman ini,

atas kesehatan dan tubuh yang sempurna bagiku ini,

atas ujian-ujian dan kesulitan-kesulitan hidup, sehingga aku bisa belajar+menjadi seseorang yang lebih baik,

atas keluarga, teman-teman, dan orang-orang di sekeliling yang melengkapi hidupku,

atas rizki yang berlimpah,

atas ilmu yang bermanfaat,

segala nikmat yang ga mungkin disebutkan semuanya karena begitu banyak dan berharganya :")
author: inasofia

title: Mari menulis
description:
Siang itu, ketika sedang asyik di depan laptop, berkutat dengan urusan kantor, sebuah pesan singkat masuk ke HP saya.

I : “Pingin nih bikin komunitas menulis”.

sebuah sms yang isinya cukup tidak terduga, di sela2 sms yang kebanyakan isinya perihal urusan kantor, sekolah atau asrama. Cukup aneh, ada kakak kelas di kampus yang tau2 ngasih tau bahwa dia mau bikin komunitas menulis, dan itu ngirimnya ke saya. muncul pertanyaan, apakah saya jago nulis sampai-sampai dia menyampaikan itu ke saya?? Berfikir sejenak, aha! Ya, saya ada skill menulis! Buka-buka file laptop dan menemukan tulisan saya di sana:

   for (int i = 1; i <= n * n; i++) {
                if (i % n == end || (i > (n-1)*n))
                {
                    res += "x";
                    end--;
                    if (end < 0) end = n-1;
              �� }
                else res += " ";
                if (i % n == 0) res += "\n";
            }

 

Hmm oke, kayaknya bukan tulisan yang seperti ini yang dia maksud, tapi karya sastra, novel, cerpen, gurindam, atau apalah itu. Kalau soal itu, wah saya nol banget. berfikir ingin membalas apa sms itu, terlintas mau mendukung keinginannya, tapi tiba2 terbayang dialog seperti ini:

A: “wah ide bagus tuh kak! Ayok bikin”
I: “maaf salah kirim”

Oh benar juga. Langsung dapat alasan cukup logis kenapa dia sms itu. Salah kirim! . Mungkin ada temannya yang jago menulis dan namanya mirip saya, entah Adi, Ali, atau Ami, dan dia salah kirim smsnya ke saya. Lantas saya balas:

A:“Salah kirim atau beneran?”

Ok, pesan terkirim. Saya kembali sibuk dengan dengan laptop, hingga beberapa saat kemudian ada balasan:

I:“Beneran”.

Oke, teorema bahwa dia salah kirim terbantahkan. Kembali teringat bahwa salah satu alasan kenapa saya bikin blog ini adalah mau belajar menulis, dan salah satu targetan di tahun 2012 saya adalah meningkatkan kemampuan menulis saya. (dan teringat blog ini udah lama nggak di tulis lagi). Akhirnya saya balas sms itu dengan dukungan positif dan mengiyakan.

Ok, mungkin ini cara Allah mengingatkan saya supaya terus belajar. Untuk pemanasan (baca: nggak dapet inspirasi mau nulis apa), jadilah saya buat postingan ini.

–

Mari menulis, karena siapa tahu, ada seseorang disana yang terinspirasi dengan tulisan kita

Mari menulis, karena siapa tahu, ada seseorang disana yang terhibur dengan tulisan kita

Mari menulis, karena siapa tahu, ada seseorang yang rindu dengan kita dan dapat terobati ketika membaca tulisan kita #loh

title: How I Became a TopCoder SRM Problem Writer
description:
I have been writing SRM problems quite often in past months. It has been a very exciting experience for me. I would like to recall how I became a problem writer in this competition…

Member SRM 489

… so I would like to suggest you to write Div-2 part of Member SRM 489. If you agree, …

Thanks,
Ivan

That was my first approval statement from mystic_tc (Ivan) for writing an SRM. Yay! I received that email after I proposed a problemset for a Member SRM. Ivan posted a “Looking for Member SRM 489 writers” thread in the forum, then I tried to propose, and I was glad that the proposal was approved. I was really really happy that time.

For those who don’t know, Member SRM is actually a regular SRM whose writers and testers are not paid. It is voluntary for keeping 3 SRM per month. That was OK for me as what I want was the experience of working together with the admins to prepare an SRM.

I actually proposed a complete set of five problems, but it turned out that the Div-1 problems did not satisfy Ivan. Yes, when I read the problems now, I realized that they are very lame problems. Therefore, Ivan assigned me to write only the Div-2 part. The Div-1 problems were written by rng_58.

After being assigned as a writer, I had to sign an agreement document and sent it to Glastonburry (Indonesia – USA, incurring an expensive JNE fee ). And then I logged in to a Java applet called MPSQAS (Member Problem Submission Quality Assurance System). This is where the complete problem statements, solutions, and test cases are uploaded to. Only approved writers can create problems there, obviously. To be approved, you must apply for a writer there (I did that after I proposed the problemset).

For Member SRM 489, Ivan also assigned two testers, vexorian and liympanda, also a language checker, eleusive. Overall, testers are responsible to submit their solutions to all problems and give feedbacks about the difficulties of the problems. The language checker is responsible to check the spelling and grammar of all statements, since most of the time the writers are not native in English. He/she also usually gives suggestions about the background stories of the problems.

While the writer writes the statements, testers will give feedbacks as a correspondence — every single feedback will be recorded in MPSQAS and emailed to all writers and testers. So, the problem creation lifecycle typically consists of writing statements, receiving feedbacks, update statements, receiving feedbacks, and so on until we are all satisfied and agree with the final statements.

My problems for this SRM were:

  • D2-250: BadVocabulary
  • D2-500: Buying Flowers
  • D2-1000: SolitaireChess

The point distribution of the problems are also discussed, moderated by Ivan, usually when the problem statements have been finalized. In this SRM, the distribution was normal, 250-500-1000 in both divisions. Quite often the distribution varies if one or more problems have more/less difficulties than usual. The easy problem is usually worth 250, 275, or 300 points; the medium 450, 500, 525, 550, or 600 points; the hard 900, 925, 950, 1000, 1050, or 1100 (very hard!) points.

After spending a lot of efforts on polishing the problems, then the match started. Writers and testers are given special accounts, writer, writer2, tester, and tester2. We can log in to the Arena as admins! With these orange handles, writers, testers, and admins:

  • are in ninja mode: we can read all whispers!
  • can read the coders’ solutions in coding phase.
  • are responsible to answer clarifications regarding the statements/constraints, usually giving “please reread statement” answers.
  • usually bet on the approximate number of solvers of each problem.
  • have fun watching the division summary. Yes, it is always fun to watch people solving our problems!

The sad part was that until the match was over, nobody solved my D2-1000 actually it was to be solved using a “classic” dynamic programming.

SRM 512

Several months later, I got an interesting problem idea which I thought would fit for a D1-Hard (PickAndDelete problem). I came up with a D2-Hard not long after that (after inventing a D1-Hard, it seems easy to come up with the rest!) and the other three problems before them, and then proposed the problemset to Ivan. Luckily, Ivan approved my entire problems and even invented a better solution for D1-Hard (N^3 –> N^2 lg N). Chmel_Tolstiy was assigned as the tester.

The points distribution for this match was unusual, 256-512-1024 for both divisions. This was Ivan’s cool idea as it was SRM numbered 512, so all problems had points that were powers of two. I think this was the first time that the point of each problem is not divisible by 25.

It turned out that there were 11 coders that solved the D1-Hard and nobody used Ivan’s faster and smarter approach. Oh, I admit that his solution is so smart that I believe I could not come up with that idea at all! That showed the true power of an SRM admin

After the match was over, Ivan asked me whether I was going to write the editorial. I accepted that request and carefully wrote my first SRM editorial, although a bit risky because it was my first time to write. Surprisingly, it seemed that many coders liked my editorial and eventually it got +39/-0 reputation.

This was my first paid SRM. I earned $525 for the problemset (five problems) and $75 for the editorial. A very good payment!

SRM 520

So this was my third SRM. I created the problemset with a nice theme, i.e., the SRM itself (what a recursive contest!). The problems were:

  • D2-250: SRMRoomAssignmentPhase
  • D2-500/D1-250: SRMCodingPhase
  • D2-1000: SRMSystemTestPhase
  • D1-500: SRMIntermissionPhase
  • D1-1000: SRMChallengePhase

See, the problem names are the phases in a usual SRM

This was the first SRM [[rng_58]] (Makoto) moderate as the new algorithm coordinator, after successfully winning TCO 2010 and TCO 2012. This was the first match after TCO 2012 finals. In this match, Makoto the new admin invented a better solution for D1-1000 and thus we raised the constraint from 50 to 2500! Like I said, SRM admin is unbeliavebly smart, whoever he is.

Mr. Dengklek, the main character, first appeared in this SRM (and then always appeared in my subsequent SRMs). He is the main character of Indonesia’s national olympiad in informatics, for those who don’t know.

I also wrote the editorial for this match. People seemed to like this editorial too, and it got +37/-1 reputation.

SRM 526

Before I competed in ACM-ICPC Asia Manila Regionals 2011, I proposed another problemset to Makoto. He accepted all problems except the D1-Hard. However, he assigned me to a match and asked me to improve the current D1-Hard or to come up with another problem.

The match would start right after I came back to Indonesia from Manila. It turned out that Makoto also competed in the same regionals. And (intermezzo) guess what, his team won the regionals, obviously!

Almost every night in Manila we discussed about the D1-Hard via chatting. Since I could not invent a good Hard for days and the match day was approaching, Makoto proposed to use his own problem, DengklekMessage (previously named FaxCiel and CielMessage). He said the problem was invented by Ivan and him together. I accepted the proposal. Makoto then asked to be a tester for the problem; I also accepted that although I was not fully confident.

One day before the contest started, I solved the hard with a simple matrix exponentiation algorithm. Makoto then said that the solution was quite trivial and he had to rewrite the problem, the statement, solution, and test cases. The current version is harder and I could not solve it before the match.

I didn’t write the editorial this time as I had so many college assignments. It was vexorian who was finally assigned to write the editorial.

SRM 532

Yet another SRM written by me. Not much to say.

For this match I created a turned-out-to-be-very-tricky D1-Easy (DengklekMakingChains). It was so tricky that during testing, Makoto counted that:

  • my solution failed twice,
  • Makoto’s solution failed twice, and
  • Ivan’s solution failed once. (he won! :p)

As all testers wrote wrong solutions for this problem, it was assigned 300 points. However, even after adding very strong examples cases, so many people still got challenged and failed the problem. Makoto even said that this problem could be a 500-pointer with arbitrary length of chains and very weak example cases.

SRM 537

This one was quite an unexpected SRM for me.

Once I proposed a complete problemset to Makoto, and (again) he approved all except the D1-Hard. Then I had a quick chat with dolphinigle asking whether he had a free D1-Hard problem, and he said he had free D1-Hard and D2-Hard problems. We agreed to make a collaborative SRM. We then tried to contacted Makoto, and he immediately approved our idea and assigned us to this match.

I heard that problem writers are rare lately; that might be why he approved to create an SRM with two writers.

Anyway, we had to agree with a common theme for the problems. I suggested the Kingdom of Ducks background story as usual, and he suggested to use <Theme>X<Name> format for the problem names. Therefore, we agreed KingX<name> for my problems and PrinceX<name> for his problems, featuring King Dengklek and Prince Gogo. A good fusion, eh?

Random thought: I still liked the example cases in my D2-Easy problem — it consists of all people preparing this match: “dolphinigle”, “gofushar”, “rngringo”, “mystictc”, “misof”, “metelsky”, and of course, “dengklek”

–

Phew, that was quite long story. To sum up, I have been a writer/one of the writers of six SRMs up to now, and I am very happy. Problem setting at TopCoder is an interesting experience! (And of course it generates revenue )

I hear that nowadays writers are not as many as they were before. If you want to try to write problems for SRM, please read the Write Problems for TopCoder page.

For those who don’t know, Member SRM is actually a regular SRM whose writers and testers are not paid. It is voluntary for keeping 3 SRM per month. That was OK for me as what I want was the experience of working together with the admins to prepare an SRM.

I actually proposed a complete set of five problems, but it turned out that the Div-1 problems did not satisfy Ivan. Yes, when I read the problems now, I realized that they are very lame problems. Therefore, Ivan assigned me to write only the Div-2 part. The Div-1 problems were written by rng_58.

After being assigned as a writer, I had to sign an agreement document and sent it to Glastonburry (Indonesia – USA, incurring an expensive JNE fee ). And then I logged in to a Java applet called MPSQAS (Member Problem Submission Quality Assurance System). This is where the complete problem statements, solutions, and test cases are uploaded to. Only approved writers can create problems there, obviously. To be approved, you must apply for a writer there (I did that after I proposed the problemset).

For Member SRM 489, Ivan also assigned two testers, vexorian and liympanda, also a language checker, eleusive. Overall, testers are responsible to submit their solutions to all problems and give feedbacks about the difficulties of the problems. The language checker is responsible to check the spelling and grammar of all statements, since most of the time the writers are not native in English. He/she also usually gives suggestions about the background stories of the problems.

While the writer writes the statements, testers will give feedbacks as a correspondence — every single feedback will be recorded in MPSQAS and emailed to all writers and testers. So, the problem creation lifecycle typically consists of writing statements, receiving feedbacks, update statements, receiving feedbacks, and so on until we are all satisfied and agree with the final statements.

My problems for this SRM were:

  • D2-250: BadVocabulary
  • D2-500: Buying Flowers
  • D2-1000: SolitaireChess

The point distribution of the problems are also discussed, moderated by Ivan, usually when the problem statements have been finalized. In this SRM, the distribution was normal, 250-500-1000 in both divisions. Quite often the distribution varies if one or more problems have more/less difficulties than usual. The easy problem is usually worth 250, 275, or 300 points; the medium 450, 500, 525, 550, or 600 points; the hard 900, 925, 950, 1000, 1050, or 1100 (very hard!) points.

After spending a lot of efforts on polishing the problems, then the match started. Writers and testers are given special accounts, writer, writer2, tester, and tester2. We can log in to the Arena as admins! With these orange handles, writers, testers, and admins:

  • are in ninja mode: we can read all whispers!
  • can read the coders’ solutions in coding phase.
  • are responsible to answer clarifications regarding the statements/constraints, usually giving “please reread statement” answers.
  • usually bet on the approximate number of solvers of each problem.
  • have fun watching the division summary. Yes, it is always fun to watch people solving our problems!

The sad part was that until the match was over, nobody solved my D2-1000 actually it was to be solved using a “classic” dynamic programming.

SRM 512

Several months later, I got an interesting problem idea which I thought would fit for a D1-Hard (PickAndDelete problem). I came up with a D2-Hard not long after that (after inventing a D1-Hard, it seems easy to come up with the rest!) and the other three problems before them, and then proposed the problemset to Ivan. Luckily, Ivan approved my entire problems and even invented a better solution for D1-Hard (N^3 –> N^2 lg N). Chmel_Tolstiy was assigned as the tester.

The points distribution for this match was unusual, 256-512-1024 for both divisions. This was Ivan’s cool idea as it was SRM numbered 512, so all problems had points that were powers of two. I think this was the first time that the point of each problem is not divisible by 25.

It turned out that there were 11 coders that solved the D1-Hard and nobody used Ivan’s faster and smarter approach. Oh, I admit that his solution is so smart that I believe I could not come up with that idea at all! That showed the true power of an SRM admin

After the match was over, Ivan asked me whether I was going to write the editorial. I accepted that request and carefully wrote my first SRM editorial, although a bit risky because it was my first time to write. Surprisingly, it seemed that many coders liked my editorial and eventually it got +39/-0 reputation.

This was my first paid SRM. I earned $525 for the problemset (five problems) and $75 for the editorial. A very good payment!

SRM 520

So this was my third SRM. I created the problemset with a nice theme, i.e., the SRM itself (what a recursive contest!). The problems were:

  • D2-250: SRMRoomAssignmentPhase
  • D2-500/D1-250: SRMCodingPhase
  • D2-1000: SRMSystemTestPhase
  • D1-500: SRMIntermissionPhase
  • D1-1000: SRMChallengePhase

See, the problem names are the phases in a usual SRM

This was the first SRM [[rng_58]] (Makoto) moderate as the new algorithm coordinator, after successfully winning TCO 2010 and TCO 2012. This was the first match after TCO 2012 finals. In this match, Makoto the new admin invented a better solution for D1-1000 and thus we raised the constraint from 50 to 2500! Like I said, SRM admin is unbeliavebly smart, whoever he is.

Mr. Dengklek, the main character, first appeared in this SRM (and then always appeared in my subsequent SRMs). He is the main character of Indonesia’s national olympiad in informatics, for those who don’t know.

I also wrote the editorial for this match. People seemed to like this editorial too, and it got +37/-1 reputation.

SRM 526

Before I competed in ACM-ICPC Asia Manila Regionals 2011, I proposed another problemset to Makoto. He accepted all problems except the D1-Hard. However, he assigned me to a match and asked me to improve the current D1-Hard or to come up with another problem.

The match would start right after I came back to Indonesia from Manila. It turned out that Makoto also competed in the same regionals. And (intermezzo) guess what, his team won the regionals, obviously!

Almost every night in Manila we discussed about the D1-Hard via chatting. Since I could not invent a good Hard for days and the match day was approaching, Makoto proposed to use his own problem, DengklekMessage (previously named FaxCiel and CielMessage). He said the problem was invented by Ivan and him together. I accepted the proposal. Makoto then asked to be a tester for the problem; I also accepted that although I was not fully confident.

One day before the contest started, I solved the hard with a simple matrix exponentiation algorithm. Makoto then said that the solution was quite trivial and he had to rewrite the problem, the statement, solution, and test cases. The current version is harder and I could not solve it before the match.

I didn’t write the editorial this time as I had so many college assignments. It was vexorian who was finally assigned to write the editorial.

SRM 532

Yet another SRM written by me. Not much to say.

For this match I created a turned-out-to-be-very-tricky D1-Easy (DengklekMakingChains). It was so tricky that during testing, Makoto counted that:

  • my solution failed twice,
  • Makoto’s solution failed twice, and
  • Ivan’s solution failed once. (he won! :p)

As all testers wrote wrong solutions for this problem, it was assigned 300 points. However, even after adding very strong examples cases, so many people still got challenged and failed the problem. Makoto even said that this problem could be a 500-pointer with arbitrary length of chains and very weak example cases.

SRM 537

This one was quite an unexpected SRM for me.

Once I proposed a complete problemset to Makoto, and (again) he approved all except the D1-Hard. Then I had a quick chat with dolphinigle asking whether he had a free D1-Hard problem, and he said he had free D1-Hard and D2-Hard problems. We agreed to make a collaborative SRM. We then tried to contacted Makoto, and he immediately approved our idea and assigned us to this match.

I heard that problem writers are rare lately; that might be why he approved to create an SRM with two writers.

Anyway, we had to agree with a common theme for the problems. I suggested the Kingdom of Ducks background story as usual, and he suggested to use <Theme>X<Name> format for the problem names. Therefore, we agreed KingX<name> for my problems and PrinceX<name> for his problems, featuring King Dengklek and Prince Gogo. A good fusion, eh?

Random thought: I still liked the example cases in my D2-Easy problem — it consists of all people preparing this match: “dolphinigle”, “gofushar”, “rngringo”, “mystictc”, “misof”, “metelsky”, and of course, “dengklek”

–

Phew, that was quite long story. To sum up, I have been a writer/one of the writers of six SRMs up to now, and I am very happy. Problem setting at TopCoder is an interesting experience! (And of course it generates revenue )

I hear that nowadays writers are not as many as they were before. If you want to try to write problems for SRM, please read the Write Problems for TopCoder page.

title: Seperangkat gadget Apple
description:
Yak.. semenjak blog ini mulai berdebu karena nggak pernah di buka lagi sama pemiliknya, Alhamdulillah, banyak hal-hal terjadi. Salah satunya adalah sekarang ini di kantor saya diproyeksikan jadi programmer iOS setelah awalnya adalah programmer Android. Kalau yang namanya programmer iOS pastinya butuh gadget iOS juga dong.. dan belum lama ini saya di “titipkan” amanah dari kantor:

Mac + iPhone

seperangkat alat ngoding iOS dibayar tunai, eh sebuah MacBook Pro dan iPhone 3GS. Project pertama saya di iOS adalah membuat sebuah aplikasi portal website berita. Sebenarnya yang bikin ngganjel adalah justru sekarang ini masa-masanya saya lagi nggak bisa terlalu fokus sama kerjaan kantor karena pikiran lagi banyak-banyaknya bercabang entah ke proyek Ukhuwah FUKI, sekolahan, Imagine Cup, dan lain-lain.

Makin banyak fasilitas berarti makin banyak kontribusi ,saatnya belajar teknologi iOS. Semoga untuk proyek-proyek kedepannya bisa lebih berkontribusi lagi

title: The Quest to Understand Consciousness
description:
“We all woke up this morning and we had with it the amazing return of our conscious mind. We recovered minds with a complete sense of self and a complete sense of our own existence — yet we hardly ever pause to consider this wonder.”

 — Antonio Damasio

title: Introducing Contest Toolkit Page
description:
I’m introducing you a new page in this blog: Contest Toolkit. You can access it by clicking the last link in the menu bar.

There are two main features of this toolkit.

Contest Problems

Past programming contest problems, such as IOIs, are often only available in PDFs — you may be too lazy to download the PDF files just to read the problems. In this section I’m planning to collect many past contest problems and transform them into more user-friendly HTML version. I’ll also try to include the solutions to all problems in their respective problem page. Furthermore, you can discuss the problems in the comment section!

The main goal of this section is to collect all problems of high school programming contests such as IOI, CEOI, and regional contests such as APIO.

Contest Materials

This section will consist of many useful links that I think are important for coders to read. From a list of online judges, tutorials, interesting blogs, and many more.

The main goal of this section is to provide a one-stop resource of all useful links for programming contest.

==

Note that this page is still in heavy construction. Your feedback or suggestion are welcome!

title: CodeSprint 2 Interview Street Problems Analysis
description:
I participated in the second CodeSprint that was held in January 7 – 8 2012. I knew this contest from a link posted in a TopCoder forum thread. As far as I know, many companies will use the result of this contest to interview new employees/interns. Because I was in holiday after the final exams, I took part in this contest, maybe somehow by luck I could get interview from some companies

The contest had three types of problems: algorithmic, company, and real-world problems. The algorithmic ones are much like usual competitive programming problems. Company problems are set by some of the companies. Real-world problems are “real”, for example, one of them is creating a web service for resizing company logos.

During the 48-hour contest (yes, only 2 days), I managed to solve 6 algorithmic problems and 1 company problem. I ranked #38 overall and #2 in Indonesia (the first rank went to dolphinigle).

Here is an analysis on some of the problems.

Algorithmic Problems

Coin Tosses (Accepted, 20/20 points)

I first tried solving this problem by transforming it into system of linear equations.

Assume that N = 3. Let f(x) be the expected number of tosses needed to make 3 consecutive heads, given that we have already x consecutive heads. Of course, the range of x is 0 <= x <= 3.

Now, let’s evaluate f(x). It is clear that f(3) = 0 (no additional tosses needed); this is the base case.

For 0 <= x < 3, there are two possibilities:

  • The next toss results in head. We have x+1 consecutive heads now, so the expected number of tosses is 1 + f(x+1).
  • The next toss results in tail. We don’t have any consecutive heads now, so the expected number of tosses is 1 + f(0).

Both cases happen with probability 1/2. Therefore, the formula for f(x), 0 <= x < 3, is:

or, more simply,

The complete formulas for N = 3 would be:




One may be tempted to solve the function using dynamic programming, but that does not work as the formulas are cyclic. For example, f(0) depends on f(1) but f(1) also depends on f(0).

Now, take a look at the equations once more. Actually it has been implicitly solved. We can work backward (back-substitution) like this:

So,


Having computed the values of f(3) and f(0), we can use them compute the value of f(2), and then f(1). We have solved the equations! This solution clearly runs in O(N) time complexity. We can precompute the results for all N and stores them in a 1000 x 1000 table. The total complexity is O(N^2 + T).

But there is a problem with this solution. Simply running this solution with large N and small M will generate a very large output that overflows double data type. Replacing double with, say, BigInteger, would probably result in TLE. So, I tried printing the results for small N and M, and then tried looking for pattern. The pattern was amazingly obvious. It turned out that the answer for this problem is simply .

This new solution can be coded in Java/Python with their built-in big integer data type, and would run fast enough for 100 test cases.

Permutation (Accepted, 14.67/25 points)

This problem is essentially an approximation to the Traveling Salesperson Problem. Just assume that the numbers are cities, and V[i][j] is the cost of going from city i to city j. A permutation of the numbers means a path that visits all cities exactly once.

The method I used was splitting the cities into blocks of 15 cities each (or may be less than 15 for the last block). Then, for each block, I did a DP with bitmask to get a Hamiltonian path considering only cities in that block, with the maximum cost.

The DP I used is two-dimensional: dp[u][mask] is the maximum cost of visiting all cities not contained in mask, given that the last visited city is u. The set mask is represented with a bitmask of n bits, where n is the number of cities in the block (15 or less).

So, the base case is

, for all u (we have visited all cities).

The recurrence is determined by choosing the next city v to visit, after visiting city u:

, for all v not in mask.

The maximum cost of a Hamiltonian path in this block is simply by choosing a starting city that leads to the maximum cost:

, for all u

The Hamiltonian paths for the other blocks are computed in the similar way, except that the starting city of a block must be the last city of the previous block.

Count Strings (Accepted, 50/50 points)

This was the hardest problem I solved in the contest. I had to learn regex parsing and converting it into finite automata, during the 48-hour contest.

First, I converted the input string into an NFA (Non-deterministic Finite Automata), and then transformed it into DFA (Deterministic Finite Automata). There is a nice tutorial and explanation on how to parse a regex into an NFA and then into DFA here.

To make it simple, a DFA is a directed graph, whose vertices are “states”, and edges are “transitions” between the states. The edges are labeled by ‘a’ or ‘b’. One vertex is marked as “starting” state and several vertices are marked as “finishing” state. A string of ‘a’ and ‘b’ is like a path in the DFA from the starting vertex. If the path ends in one of the finishing vertices, then the DFA is said to “match” or to “accept” the string.

For example, the input ((a|b)(a*)) 5 can be parsed into this DFA:

      --a-->[1]--a
     /           |   ----+
     |           v  /    |
[O]--+          [3]*--a-->
     |           ^
     \           |
      --b-->[2]--a

The starting vertex is vertex 0, while the finishing vertices are vertices 1, 2, and 3. Any string that leads to a path from vertex 0 to any of the vertices 1, 2, and 3 is accepted by the regex (try it with several such strings). Now, the problem is to count the number of strings which lead to paths of length 5 starting from vertex 0 that end in vertex 1, 2, or 3.

Let’s build the adjacency matrix of the above graph:

It is well-known that is actually the number of paths from i to j of length 1. More generally, is the number of paths from i to j of length n. Therefore, here are the steps to solve this problem:

  • Construct a DFA from the input regex.
  • Build M, the adjacency matrix of the resulting DFA.
  • Raise M to the L-th power, using exponentiation by squaring.
  • Sum all , where x is the starting vertex and y is a finishing vertex, for all y.

The hardest part is actually constructing the DFA. It took me several hours straight to learn the construct it from the above link.

Picking Cards (Accepted, 20/20 points)

First, sort the input in ascending order. For example, let the sorted input be 0, 0, 1, 1, 4. Consider the cards one-by-one. For each card, we will count how many ways to pick up to that card.

  • The first card has c = 0. Because we haven’t picked any cards yet, it can be picked. There are only 1 way: {1}.
  • The second card has c = 0. The smallest valid position for this card is the first position. So, there are 2 ways: {2, x}, {1, x}.
  • The third card has c = 1. The smallest valid position for this card is the second position. So, there are 2 ways: {x, 3, x}, {x, x, 3}.
  • The fourth card has c = 1. The smallest valid position for this card is the second position. So, there are 3 ways: {x, 4, x, x}, {x, x, 4, x}, {x, x, x, 4}.
  • The last card has c = 4. The smallest valid position for this card is the fifth position. So, there are 1 way: {x, x, x, x, 5}.

In each step, the ‘x’s can be replaced with any valid sequence from the previous step. Therefore, the total number of ways is 1 x 2 x 2 x 3 x 1 = 12.

The smallest valid position for the -th card (1-indexed) is . The total number of valid positions for that card is then (or 0, if ). Therefore, the total number of ways is:

Subsequence Weighting (Accepted, 30/30 points)

Let’s try solving it with a simple dynamic programming solution. Let be the maximum weight of a subsequence that ends in . The recurrence would be

, where and .

Note that if we fill the dp table in ascending order of , and in decreasing order of for the same values of , and set the unfilled entries of the dp table to 0, we can reduce the constraints into the above dp into:

, where .

The value of “, where ” can be computed efficiently in O(log N) time complexity using a binary indexed tree. The solution to the original problem is then for all i. So, the total time complexity of this solution is O(N log N).

Direct Connections (Accepted, 35/35 points)

The problem essentially asks for the sum of cable length for each pair of cities, where the cable length for a pair of city i and city j is .

Consider the cities in ascending order of . Now, the equation turns into the sum of , for all i and for all previous cities j of i. Moreover, the absolute sign can be removed by transforming the equation into the sum of , for all i and for all previous cities to the left of city i, plus , for all i and for all previous cities to the right of city i.

Let’s solve for the sum of (the right one can be solved in similar way). If there are previous cities to the left of city , the equation becomes .

Hence, for each city (again, considered in ascending order of ), we need to know two pieces of information:

  • The number of previous cities to the left of it ()
  • The sum of positions of all previous cities to the left of it (

These two values can be computed using (again) two binary indexed trees in O(log N) each. One BIT stores the number of cities to the left of a certain position, and the other BIT stores the sum of positions of all cities to the left of a certain position. By position I meant the “rank” of a city when the cities are sorted in ascending order of .

Polygon (Not Attempted, 0/40 points)

dolphinigle posted his solution in a TopCoder forum thread.

Crab Graphs (Not Attempted, 0/40 points)

I honestly had no idea on this problem. Several guys discussed this problem on the same thread as Polygon; please check that.

Company Problems

Quora Nearby (Accepted, 40/40 points)

At first I thought this problem must be solved using some sophisticated Kd-tree data structure, with some kind of nearest-neighbor search algorithm. But, when I decided to try a simple naive search (O(N) for topics and O(N^2) for questions), I got accepted!

Fraud Prevention (Wrong Answer, 15/30 points)

I submitted like 20+ solutions for this problem, but I couldn’t pass the last test case. I don’t know, may be I missed something in the problem. What I did is a simple O(N^2) search to look for all pairs of fraudulent orders (it didn’t get TLE, though). For each pair, I checked if they satisfy one of the fraudulent requirement.

===

That’s it. If anyone would add alternate solutions or anything, please add them in the comment section
